content_scrubbed:
There is a line in the Philip Roth novel *The Human Stain* where two members of the WASP academic old guard are lamenting the influx of Jewish students at their Northeastern liberal_arts college because "they make things competitive." Your situation might be analogous. 

I imagine that many admissions officers and interviewers are not exactly comfortable with using a wholly meritocratic system to gauge exactly who gets to attend their alma mater and what exactly needs to be done to get there. Self-motivation, leadership, love of learning these are vague cues and yet many of the gatekeepers believe they can parse them out after the baseline of exceptional grades have been met. It[.] debate worth having between a completely transparent and implicit system where hard_work and sacrifice are duly rewarded against an instinctual system affirmed by those who by virtue of attending and excelling at their institution understand it[.] purpose and who belongs there albeit by going about it in an opaque way.

As for your Korean friend her white-passing name might in a vacuum be a boon or at least a non-issue which in our world is itself an advantage.

The affirmative action aspect of your question is a difficult one to answer in part because of the contentiousness of the issue especially among Asians. Consider the situation not in such an adversarial way but as a result of policy decisions that have the aim of remedying centuries of institutional prejudice and increasing the presence of blacks, natives, latinos etc. at universities. I understand though that might be of little consolation.
